poem:
**Flags in the Wind**

In the park, a flag  
flickers—green, white crisscrossed  
by black and red veins.  
The leaves whisper freedoms,   
unthreatened by steel stern eyes.  
A warning, say the guns:  
speak too loudly,  
and we shall turn  
peace to proscribed sound.  
Yet the wind knows not  
its own colors—  
or consent.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Police may be trying to criminalise all Palestine protests. But we will march on | Letter Your report that armed police threatened to arrest a protester for holding a Palestine flag, citing grounds that she might support a proscribed terror organisation (Report, 17 July), is truly chilling. It shows that the police are either completely ignorant of the law or – more likely – that they are using the proscription of a peaceful, non-violent direct". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
